As members of Congress, we have an obligation ‚Äì not to party ‚Äì but to our Constitution, our country and to the truth. It remains my hope that throughout this process we will continue upholding our sworn oaths and follow the facts on behalf of Americans ‚Äî wherever they may lead.

If the Trump Administration continues to stonewall, it is my hope that the courts force the Administration to turn over pertinent information so the House can do its job. I will not prejudge the outcome of the House‚Äôs process, but they must be able to move forward.
Right now, the Trump Administration is stonewalling and trying to stop the House ‚Äî part of a coequal branch of our government ‚Äî from doing its job during this impeachment inquiry.

Next, if the House votes to indict ‚Äì it‚Äôs up to us in the Senate to do our jobs. That evidence is presented to members of the Senate who act as jurors.

If we get to that point, I am wholly prepared to do my job.

First, the House of Representatives acts a grand jury ‚Äì it gathers information, or the evidence, related to the alleged possible misdeed. If the House finds there is sufficient evidence, then members of the House would vote on the articles of impeachment.

In that Constitution, first ratified by the state of Delaware, our Founding Fathers devised a process in case the President of our country is suspected to be involved in inappropriate or unlawful behavior.

We can‚Äôt go more than a few hours without more news emerging about the President‚Äôs dealings and the dealings of those around him. As new information comes out, I support the House's efforts to sift through the facts ‚Äî the first step in a process enshrined in our Constitution.

What our country needs right now is for elected officials on both sides of the aisle to uphold our oath, display some courage and speak out. As members of Congress, we have an obligation ‚Äì not to party ‚Äì but to our Constitution, our country and to the truth.

History is watching.

In the past week, we‚Äôve watched the president publicly ask two foreign governments to interfere in our elections by investigating his political opponent. He told the American people he ‚Äúhas that right‚Äù and that it‚Äôs his ‚Äúduty."

This is the kind of behavior our Founders feared.

In our U.S. Constitution, our Founders included safeguards against foreign influence, like the emoluments clause. And they devised an intricate system of checks and balances. They disagreed on many things, but they did agree that they did not want an all-powerful king.

The threats posed to our democracy by foreign interference in our U.S. election system are not new. In fact, it was an issue our Founders feared. And when they met at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, they discussed ways to protect our democracy from it.
